G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant was Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord who “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant” is liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, together with reasonable attorneys’ fees and costs.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Somerville District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 and applicable District Court venue rules because the Property is located in Somerville, Middlesex County, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this action occurred there.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: An award of prejudgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by G.L. c. 231, § 6B and other applicable law;

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.proposition: In addition to the express lease provision, Massachusetts law implies in every residential tenancy a covenant of quiet enjoyment. See G.L. c. 186, § 14; Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715–18 (1977); Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly recognizes and applies an *implied* covenant (or warranty) of quiet enjoyment in favor of the tenants—so it does support the idea that such an implied covenant exists in Massachusetts. However, the proposition as phrased adds that this covenant is implied “in every residential tenancy” and ties it explicitly to G.L. c. 186, § 14. Blackett does not discuss § 14 or universally announce that the implied covenant applies in every residential tenancy; instead it addresses constructive eviction and landlord responsibility for noise from a bar. Thus, it partially but not fully supports the broader, statutory formulation in the proposition.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.relevant_excerpt: He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). The landlords argue that they did not violate the tenants’ implied covenant of quiet enjoyment because they are not chargeable with the noise from the lounge. Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment and occupation of the whole or part of the leased premises.

Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.proposition: In addition to the express lease provision, Massachusetts law implies in every residential tenancy a covenant of quiet enjoyment. See G.L. c. 186, § 14; Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715–18 (1977); Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929).
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.support_reasoning:
The case recognizes an implied obligation arising from the lease, but it is not framed as a general, statutory, or universal implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in all (particularly residential) tenancies. Instead, the court relies on common-law principles that a lease carries an implication that the lessor will refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken that substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises, and then analyzes the tenant’s parallel tort and nuisance-type claims. It does not ground an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in G.L. c. 186, § 14 or articulate a universal rule for every residential tenancy.

Thus, while related to quiet enjoyment concepts, Winchester v. O’Brien does not clearly stand for the broader proposition that Massachusetts law implies in every residential tenancy a covenant of quiet enjoyment as later codified and discussed in cases like Blackett v. Olanoff.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.relevant_excerpt: “The ‘grant of any thing carries an implication, that the grantee shall have all that is necessary to the enjoyment of the grant, so far as the grantor has power to give it.’ … The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … The defendants contend that the bill is framed solely on a breach of an implied covenant for quiet enjoyment and cannot be maintained. … The bill is not based solely on breach of the implied covenant.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. at 718\u2.raw_text: Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. at 718–19 (landlord may be liable for interference with quiet enjoyment caused by other tenants when landlord’s actions or inactions make the interference foreseeable and unremedied).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. at 718\u2.proposition: Defendant’s inaction and dismissive response effectively condoned or acquiesced in the conduct of the Upstairs Tenants and allowed the disturbance to continue unabated.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. at 716\u2.proposition: The interference Plaintiff experiences is not trivial or transient; it is substantial, unreasonable, and of a kind that a reasonable tenant would find materially impairs the use and enjoyment of a dwelling. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. at 716–18; Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994).

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The interference Plaintiff experiences is not trivial or transient; it is substantial, unreasonable, and of a kind that a reasonable tenant would find materially impairs the use and enjoyment of a dwelling. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. at 716–18; Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that if the plaintiffs are unable to use the common areas due to the drug activity, that situation is a “serious interference” with quiet enjoyment that “substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.” This aligns with the proposition that the interference is not trivial or transient but substantial and of a kind that materially impairs use and enjoyment of the dwelling. The court then remands specifically to determine the seriousness or substantiality of that interference, confirming that this is the operative standard.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly applied G.L. c. 186, § 14 to protect tenants from substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment caused by the acts of third parties where the landlord is in a position to control or prevent the interference. See, e.g.:
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion strongly supports the substantive *principle* that a landlord is liable for substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment caused by others where the landlord created the situation and has the power to control or prevent the interference. However, the decision is framed in terms of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction, not as an application or interpretation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, and it does not cite or rely on that statute. Thus it is good authority for the common‑law rule, but not for the statutory proposition as worded.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge. To the extent that our opinions suggest a distinction between nonfeasance by the landlord… and malfeasance by the landlord, we decline to perpetuate that distinction where the landlord creates a situation and has the right to control the objectionable conditions.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly applied G.L. c. 186, § 14 to protect tenants from substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment caused by the acts of third parties where the landlord is in a position to control or prevent the interference. See, e.g.:
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court squarely applies G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the quiet enjoyment statute) to substantial interferences caused by third-party criminal/drug activity in common areas, focusing on the landlord’s omissions where it had control over the premises and could take measures (e.g., actions under c. 121B, § 32C) to remove or restrict such third parties. The opinion holds that if the landlord takes no or inadequate action to remove such nontenant wrongdoers from property it owns and controls, and their presence seriously interferes with tenants’ use, the landlord may be liable for breach of quiet enjoyment. That aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts courts apply § 14 to protect tenants against substantial interferences from third parties where the landlord is in a position to control or prevent the interference.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: "We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.... If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment."

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly applied G.L. c. 186, § 14 to protect tenants from substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment caused by the acts of third parties where the landlord is in a position to control or prevent the interference. See, e.g.:
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the level of landlord fault required under G.L. c. 186, § 14 (at least negligence and notice/foreseeability), but it does not address interference caused by third parties or a landlord’s duty to control third-party conduct. The only third-party-related reference is a citation to Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority in a footnote, which itself concerned the landlord’s failure to act, not third-party acts. Thus, this case does not support the specific proposition about third-party interference.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: Indeed, in each case since the 1973 statutory revision in which we have recognized a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, there was evidence that the landlord failed to act reasonably in the circumstances concerning a problem known to the landlord, and the natural and probable consequences of such failure caused the interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises. See, e.g., Cruz, supra at 790; Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285-288 (1994)7; Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979).

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly applied G.L. c. 186, § 14 to protect tenants from substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment caused by the acts of third parties where the landlord is in a position to control or prevent the interference. See, e.g.:
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns landlord liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment caused by third parties, where the landlord is in a position to control or prevent the interference. Simon v. Solomon does apply § 14 broadly to serious interferences with quiet enjoyment and rejects the landlord’s argument that third-party conduct breaks the chain of responsibility, but the third-party aspect here involves other tenants misusing plumbing, not the more general or repeated line of cases the proposition suggests. The opinion is a significant data point, but it does not itself show that Massachusetts courts have ‘repeatedly’ applied § 14 in third‑party‑interference scenarios; it is better characterized as one such application rather than evidence of a repeated line of authority.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “As its third objection to Solomon’s recovery on her count for interference with quiet enjoyment, Gem asserts that it was wrongly held responsible for the actions of third parties beyond its control… Gem argues that it was unable to control the source of the flooding… This contention echoes Gem’s objections to the verdict for reckless infliction of emotional distress, and we reject it for the same reasons. The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent… Therefore, Gem is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

Aguayo v. Donahue, 2012 Mass. App. Div..raw_text: Aguayo v. Donahue, 2012 Mass. App. Div. 113 (App. Div.)
Aguayo v. Donahue, 2012 Mass. App. Div..proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly applied G.L. c. 186, § 14 to protect tenants from substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment caused by the acts of third parties where the landlord is in a position to control or prevent the interference. See, e.g.:
Aguayo v. Donahue, 2012 Mass. App. Div..support_reasoning: The opinion in Aguayo v. Donahue (actually involving Kerans and Baranauskas) concerns contract formation and quantum meruit recovery for renovation work on a condominium. It does not involve landlord‑tenant law, G.L. c. 186, § 14, quiet enjoyment, or third‑party interference. Therefore it cannot serve as authority for the proposition that Massachusetts courts apply § 14 to protect tenants from third‑party interferences with quiet enjoyment.
Aguayo v. Donahue, 2012 Mass. App. Div..relevant_excerpt: Consequently, what we have in this case is a plaintiff appearing to claim that he has a right to recover damages on a quantum meruit theory, and a defendant clearly claiming that there was a contract, that the plaintiff violated it, and that she therefore owed nothing. As to the former, “Quantum meruit is a theory of recovery, not a cause of action. It is a claim independent of an assertion for damages under the contract… Recovery under this theory is derived from the principles of equity and fairness….”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly applied G.L. c. 186, § 14 to protect tenants from substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment caused by the acts of third parties where the landlord is in a position to control or prevent the interference. See, e.g.:
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The case applies G.L. c. 186, § 14 to a landlord’s own failure to provide heat, not to interferences caused by third parties. The opinion discusses quiet enjoyment and § 14 liability in terms of the landlord’s conduct (failure to furnish heat) and expressly relies on Blackett and Simon for the governing standard; it does not address landlord responsibility for third‑party acts or control over third‑party behavior. Thus it does not support the specific proposition about third‑party interferences.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “It was claimed that the defendants had violated those portions of G. L. c. 186, § 14…which impose civil liability on a landlord ‘who willfully or intentionally fails to furnish…heat…or…who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant….’ … A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.… [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly applied G.L. c. 186, § 14 to protect tenants from substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment caused by the acts of third parties where the landlord is in a position to control or prevent the interference. See, e.g.:
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.support_reasoning: The opinion does concern substantial interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment, but it is decided on common-law theories (implied covenant, trespass, nuisance, equitable relief), not under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The statute is never cited or applied, and the liability is framed in terms of acts ‘done or authorized by the defendants’ themselves, not third-party acts the landlord failed to control. Thus, Winchester v. O’Brien does not serve as authority for the specific statutory proposition stated.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.relevant_excerpt: “It is evident from the facts found that there has been a substantial and continued interference with the plaintiff’s beneficial enjoyment of the leased premises and appurtenant rights by the acts done or authorized by the defendants… The bill is not based solely on breach of the implied covenant. The same act may be a breach of the covenant for quiet enjoyment and also a wrong causing injury to the tenant for which injunctive relief might be sought or an action of tort would lie.”

Rubin v. Prescott, 362 Mass. 281 (1972).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly applied G.L. c. 186, § 14 to protect tenants from substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment caused by the acts of third parties where the landlord is in a position to control or prevent the interference. See, e.g.:
Rubin v. Prescott, 362 Mass. 281 (1972).support_reasoning: The opinion in Rubin v. Prescott does not discuss G.L. c. 186, § 14, quiet enjoyment, or landlord responsibility for third‑party interference. It addresses summary process, the status of tenants at sufferance, the effect of State Sanitary Code violations, and the application of G.L. c. 239, § 8A. Because the case never analyzes quiet enjoyment or third‑party acts, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that Massachusetts courts apply § 14 to protect tenants from such interferences.
Rubin v. Prescott, 362 Mass. 281 (1972).relevant_excerpt: The tenants have argued an exception on the issue whether the landlord commenced these cases in reprisal for the acts of the tenants for reporting alleged violations of the State Sanitary Code to the housing authorities. G. L. c. 186, § 18, inserted by St. 1969, c. 701, § 1, and c. 239, § 2A, inserted by St. 1969, c. 701, § 2. This issue was not included in the four stipulated issues on which the case was tried, and is not properly before us.

Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004)
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly applied G.L. c. 186, § 14 to protect tenants from substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment caused by the acts of third parties where the landlord is in a position to control or prevent the interference. See, e.g.:
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case does apply G.L. c. 186, § 14 to protect tenants from serious interferences with their tenancy, but the interference here stems from defective ventilation and resulting fire/moisture/odors, not from the acts of third parties. The opinion does not discuss landlord liability for disturbances or harms caused by third parties under the landlord’s control, so it does not specifically support the third‑party aspect of the proposition, even though it reinforces the general quiet‑enjoyment standard under § 14.
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees tenants the right to be free from ‘serious’ interferences with their tenancies. See G. L. c. 186, § 14; Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); Ianello v. Court Mgmt. Corp., 400 Mass. 321, 323-324 (1987). A landlord violates G. L. c. 186, § 14, when its ‘acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises.’ Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789 (1994). Here, the judge found that the landlord knowingly rented the premises in a defective condition and failed to correct the ventilation problem…”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987) (per curiam)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly applied G.L. c. 186, § 14 to protect tenants from substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment caused by the acts of third parties where the landlord is in a position to control or prevent the interference. See, e.g.:
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion in Young v. Patukonis does not discuss G.L. c. 186, § 14 at all, nor does it address landlord liability for substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment caused by third parties. The case concerns issues of the State Sanitary Code, security deposits under § 15B, Boston rent control, warranty of habitability, and G.L. c. 93A, but contains no analysis of quiet enjoyment or third‑party conduct. It therefore does not support the stated proposition and appears to be a miscitation for that purpose.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt:
Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs.
...
E. General Laws c. 93A.
Young, as an owner-occupant of a three-family building, whose primary objective is personal, is not subject to G. L. c. 93A. That claim was properly dismissed.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. at 718\u2.raw_text: Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. at 718–19 (landlord liable where failure to take appropriate action contributed to continuing disturbance)
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. at 718\u2.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act, coupled with his statement that he “can’t control how people live,” constitutes at least negligent, and in context arguably willful, interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102\u2013.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act, coupled with his statement that he “can’t control how people live,” constitutes at least negligent, and in context arguably willful, interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102 (reco.raw_text: Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102 (recognizing that repeated, severe interferences are actionable)
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102 (reco.proposition: The interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment is neither de minimis nor sporadic; rather, it is serious, recurring, and has persisted over a substantial period of time.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102 (reco.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly treats repeated, serious flooding over years as an actionable interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and emphasizes the “long and repetitious course” and “repeated flooding” as the basis for liability. The court describes approximately thirty nocturnal floods with sewage water over Solomon’s multi‑year tenancy and holds that such recurrent conditions interfered with her quiet enjoyment, thereby confirming that non‑de minimis, persistent interferences over a substantial period are actionable.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102 (reco.relevant_excerpt:
“Solomon testified that she had repeatedly complained to Gem of floods. She stated that Gem on each occasion sent a cleanup crew to pump out the water, but never took permanent action. The jury, if they believed this testimony, could find that Gem knew or should have known that unless it fixed the porous wall flooding would occur… The jury could also find that Gem had displayed, over a long and repetitious course, such a pattern of indifference that its conduct was outrageous…
…[Gem] permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. at 283–84.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment is neither de minimis nor sporadic; rather, it is serious, recurring, and has persisted over a substantial period of time.

Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. at 85.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Defendant is liable to Plaintiff for her actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, together with reasonable attorneys’ fees and costs. See Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. at 850–51; Aguayo v. Donahue, 2012 Mass. App. Div. 113.

Aguayo v. Donahue, 2012 Mass. App. Div..raw_text: Aguayo v. Donahue, 2012 Mass. App. Div. 113
Aguayo v. Donahue, 2012 Mass. App. Div..proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Defendant is liable to Plaintiff for her actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, together with reasonable attorneys’ fees and costs. See Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. at 850–51; Aguayo v. Donahue, 2012 Mass. App. Div. 113.
Aguayo v. Donahue, 2012 Mass. App. Div..support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns a contractor–owner dispute over renovation work and addresses contract formation versus quantum meruit. It does not mention G.L. c. 186, § 14, tenant remedies, three months’ rent, or attorneys’ fees and costs. Nothing in the case establishes or applies the statutory damages rule described in the proposition, so citing this case for that proposition is inaccurate.
Aguayo v. Donahue, 2012 Mass. App. Div..relevant_excerpt: Consequently, what we have in this case is a plaintiff appearing to claim that he has a right to recover damages on a quantum meruit theory, and a defendant clearly claiming that there was a contract, that the plaintiff violated it, and that she therefore owed nothing. As to the former, “Quantum meruit is a theory of recovery, not a cause of action. It is a claim independent of an assertion for damages under the contract, although both claims have as a common basis the contract itself.”
